Eli Manning: Reflecting on a Legendary Career and the Excitement of the NFL Playoffs

Former New York Giants quarterback Eli Manning, a two-time Super Bowl champion, recently shared his thoughts on his illustrious career, the current NFL playoffs, and his ongoing involvement in the sport.

A Legendary Career

"I'm very proud of what I accomplished during my time in the NFL," Manning said. "I was fortunate to play with some incredible teammates and coaches, and we had some amazing moments together."

Manning, known for his calm demeanor and clutch performances, led the Giants to two Super Bowl victories over the New England Patriots, quarterbacked by the legendary Tom Brady.

"Those Super Bowl wins were the highlights of my career," Manning said. "It's something I'll never forget."

Excitement for the Playoffs

With the NFL playoffs in full swing, Manning is excited about the upcoming matchups, particularly the NFC Divisional round clash between Drew Brees and Tom Brady.

"It's going to be a great game," Manning said. "Drew Brees and Tom Brady are two of the greatest quarterbacks of all time, and it's always special to watch them play."

Life After Football

Since retiring from the NFL, Manning has kept a relatively low profile compared to his older brother, Peyton Manning. He has focused on charity work and brand endorsements.

"I'm enjoying my retirement," Manning said. "I'm spending more time with my family and friends, and I'm involved in some great causes."

Stella Stadium Bites

One of Manning's current projects is Stella Stadium Bites, a Super Bowl food ideas initiative. He is collaborating with former Giants wide receiver Victor Cruz on the project.

"Stella Stadium Bites is a great way to bring people together over food and football," Cruz said. "We're excited to be a part of it."

Rivalry with Tom Brady

Despite his two Super Bowl victories over Brady, Manning holds no ill will towards his former rival.

"Tom Brady is a great player," Manning said. "He's one of the best to ever play the game."

Manning emphasized the importance of team effort in their Super Bowl victories.

"It wasn't just me," Manning said. "We had a great team, and we all played our part."

Playing Smart Football

Manning also discussed the importance of playing smart football against teams like the Patriots.

"You have to be smart against teams like the Patriots," Manning said. "They're going to try to trick you and make you make mistakes."

Relationship with Peyton Manning

Eli and Peyton Manning have a close relationship, and they often talk about football.

"We talk about football all the time," Eli Manning said. "We break down games and analyze players."

Despite being considered the quieter Manning brother, Eli has fond memories of watching Super Bowls with his family.

"We would all get together and watch the Super Bowl," Eli Manning said. "It was a special time."

Appreciation for Brees and Brady

Manning expressed admiration for the longevity and skill of both Drew Brees and Tom Brady, who continue to play at a high level into their 40s.

"It's amazing what they're doing," Manning said. "They're both still playing at a very high level, and it's a testament to their hard work and dedication."

Conclusion

Eli Manning's legacy as one of the greatest quarterbacks of his generation is secure. He is a two-time Super Bowl champion, a respected analyst, and a dedicated philanthropist. As he continues to enjoy his retirement, Manning remains passionate about football and is excited about the future of the sport.

Capitol Riot: Lawmakers Condemn Violence, Some Call Rioters 'Patriots'

Washington, D.C. - Lawmakers have expressed outrage over the violence that erupted at the Capitol on Wednesday, with some condemning the rioters as "domestic terrorists" while others referred to them as "patriots."

The riot, which was emboldened by President Donald Trump and Republican rally attendees, including state lawmakers, resulted in the deaths of at least five people, including one police officer.

One GOP state lawmaker, Derrick Evans of West Virginia, has resigned after attending the rally before the riot. The rally, which supported Trump's efforts to overturn the 2020 election results, was attended by Republican lawmakers who echoed the president's baseless claims of voter fraud.

Rioters, including members of the Proud Boys, classified as a hate group, stormed the Capitol building during the certification of the election results, in an attempted coup. Investigations into the riot are ongoing.

A Senate aide, Eugene Goodman, secured the electoral vote boxes during the riot, ensuring they were not damaged. Despite the violence, the vote to certify President-elect Joe Biden proceeded hours later, and Trump promised an orderly transition.

Calls for Trump's impeachment on charges of "incitement of an insurrection" have emerged, as well as backlash against Republican lawmakers who attended the rally.

Lawmakers' Reactions

Democratic lawmakers have condemned the violence, calling it an attack on democracy. House Speaker Nancy Pelosi said, "This was not a protest. This was an insurrection."

Republican lawmakers have been more divided in their reactions. Some, like Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell, have condemned the violence, while others have downplayed it or defended the rioters.

Senator Josh Hawley (R-MO), who objected to the certification of the election results, said, "I do not believe that the violence we saw today was the result of anything that I said."

Ongoing Investigations

The FBI is investigating the riot, and several arrests have been made. The House of Representatives has also launched an impeachment inquiry into Trump's role in inciting the violence.

Backlash Against Republican Lawmakers

Republican lawmakers who attended the rally before the riot are facing backlash from their constituents and fellow party members. Some have been censured or stripped of their committee assignments.

The Republican National Committee has also condemned the violence, saying, "The violence and destruction that took place at the Capitol today was unacceptable and un-American."

Conclusion

The Capitol riot was a dark day for American democracy. The violence and attempted coup were a direct result of Trump's baseless claims of voter fraud and the support he received from Republican lawmakers.

The ongoing investigations will shed light on the extent of the conspiracy and the role played by Trump and his allies. The backlash against Republican lawmakers who supported Trump's efforts to overturn the election results is a sign that the country is not willing to tolerate such behavior.

Cuomo Nursing Home Scandal: AG Report Reveals Massive Underreporting of Deaths

New York City, NY - A bombshell report released by New York Attorney General Letitia James has exposed a shocking cover-up of COVID-19 nursing home deaths by the state's Department of Health, with the true toll potentially 50% higher than previously reported.

Underreporting and Misdirection

"Our investigation revealed that the New York State Department of Health failed to accurately and completely count the number of deaths that occurred in nursing homes due to COVID-19," James stated. "This resulted in a gross undercount of the true toll of the pandemic on our most vulnerable population."

The report alleges that the Cuomo administration directed nursing homes to accept COVID-19 patients, a decision that critics say contributed to the high death rates among elderly residents.

Media Complicity and Conflict of Interest

Governor Andrew Cuomo's handling of the nursing home crisis has also come under fire for his frequent appearances on his brother Chris Cuomo's CNN program, where he largely avoided discussing the issue.

"CNN's coverage of the Cuomo nursing home scandal has been a disgrace," said media critic William A. Jacobson. "They have repeatedly given Andrew Cuomo a platform to deflect criticism and avoid accountability."

When the nursing home controversy was finally addressed on CNN, Gov. Cuomo deflected criticism with jokes, sparking outrage among viewers.

"CNN's mishandling of the Cuomo brothers' interviews is a clear conflict of interest," said journalist Glenn Greenwald. "They have failed to hold Andrew Cuomo accountable for his actions."

Political Bias and Media Watchdogs

The Cuomo nursing home scandal has ignited a firestorm of criticism from both sides of the political spectrum.

"The liberal media has been quick to praise Andrew Cuomo in the past, but they have been silent on his handling of the nursing home crisis," said Steve Krakauer, a former CNN digital producer and media watchdog. "This is a clear case of political bias."

Cuomo's Defense and Blame Game

Gov. Cuomo has defended his nursing home policy, blaming the Trump administration for COVID-related issues.

"The federal government failed to provide us with the resources we needed to fight this pandemic," Cuomo said. "We did the best we could with the information we had at the time."

Leadership and Accountability

Cuomo, once lauded by the liberal media as a beacon of leadership, has seen his reputation tarnished by the nursing home scandal. He has authored a book on leadership and received an Emmy Award for his handling of the pandemic.

However, the attorney general's report suggests that Cuomo's mandated admission of COVID-19 patients into nursing homes may have increased residents' risk.

Media Scrutiny and Public Outrage

The Cuomo nursing home scandal has sparked intense media scrutiny and public outrage. Media watchdogs and commentators on both sides have criticized the coverage and handling of the issue.

"The media has failed to hold Andrew Cuomo accountable for his actions," said Jacobson. "They have allowed him to evade responsibility and deflect blame."

Calls for Investigation and Transparency

The attorney general's report has prompted calls for a full-scale investigation into the Cuomo administration's handling of the nursing home crisis.

"We need to get to the bottom of what happened and hold those responsible accountable," said James. "The families of the victims deserve justice."

Conclusion

The Cuomo nursing home scandal has exposed a systemic failure in New York's handling of the COVID-19 pandemic. The underreporting of deaths, the governor's questionable directives, and the complicity of the media have raised serious questions about leadership, accountability, and the integrity of our institutions. As the investigation continues, the full extent of the tragedy and the consequences for those responsible remain to be seen.

Biden's COVID-19 Strategy: A Resounding Success

Washington, D.C. - President Biden's comprehensive COVID-19 strategy has achieved remarkable success, leading to the administration of 300 million vaccine doses within 150 days. This unprecedented vaccination drive has significantly lowered COVID-19 cases, hospitalizations, and deaths, bringing the nation closer to overcoming the pandemic.

A Slow Start, a Swift Turnaround

When President Biden took office in January 2021, only 5% of adult Americans were vaccinated against COVID-19. The initial pace of vaccinations was slow, with limited vaccine supply and insufficient distribution channels.

Recognizing the urgent need to accelerate the vaccination effort, the Biden Administration swiftly implemented a multifaceted strategy that included securing vaccine supply, increasing vaccination sites, and mobilizing federal personnel.

Securing Vaccine Supply

The Administration worked tirelessly to secure a steady supply of vaccines, negotiating with manufacturers to increase production and delivery schedules. This proactive approach ensured that there were ample vaccines available to meet the growing demand.

Expanding Vaccination Sites

To make vaccines more accessible to Americans, the Administration established over 81,000 vaccination sites across the country. This vast network of sites ensured that most Americans could get vaccinated within 5 miles of their homes.

The federal pharmacy vaccination program was also expanded to include 42,000 local pharmacies, administering over 82 million shots. Additionally, 39 federally-run, high-volume vaccination sites were set up, particularly in vulnerable neighborhoods.

Mobilizing Federal Personnel

The Administration deployed federal personnel to support vaccination efforts, including the National Guard, FEMA, and the Public Health Service. These personnel assisted with site setup, vaccine administration, and logistics, ensuring smooth and efficient operations.

Community Health Centers: A Vital Role

Community health centers played a significant role in the vaccination effort, especially for the poverty-line population and racial/ethnic minorities. These centers hosted almost 11,000 pop-up clinics, bringing vaccines directly to underserved communities.

Equity at the Forefront

The Biden Administration emphasized equity in vaccine distribution, with a majority of federally-provided shots going to people of color. The Administration also supported over 20,000 community-based pop-up vaccination clinics, targeting areas with low vaccination rates.

Results that Speak Volumes

The success of the Biden Administration's COVID-19 strategy is evident in the dramatic decline in COVID-19 cases, hospitalizations, and deaths. As of July 4, 2021, over 175 million Americans have received at least one COVID-19 vaccine dose, with 65% of adult Americans having gotten at least one shot and 55% being fully vaccinated.

A Call to Action

While significant progress has been made, the Biden Administration urges all Americans to get vaccinated as soon as possible. Vaccination is the most effective way to protect oneself, loved ones, and the community from COVID-19.

The Administration continues to work diligently to ensure that every American has access to a COVID-19 vaccine, regardless of their location, background, or financial means. Together, we can defeat this pandemic and build a healthier future for all.

House Democrats Forge Ahead with Impeachment as Senate Trial Looms

In the aftermath of the violent Capitol insurrection, House Democrats are swiftly moving towards impeaching President Trump for a second time, citing his role in inciting the attack as an "imminent threat" to democracy and the Constitution.

House Speaker Nancy Pelosi, in a letter to colleagues, outlined the plan, stating, "The President's dangerous and seditious acts necessitate our urgent action." She added, "We must hold him accountable for his actions and prevent him from doing further harm to our democracy."

The impeachment effort includes two parallel tracks: adopting a resolution under the 25th Amendment to remove Trump from office and drafting articles of impeachment accusing him of inciting violence against the U.S. government.

Pelosi and Senate Minority Leader Charles Schumer attempted to contact Vice President Pence to discuss the 25th Amendment resolution but were unable to connect. The resolution, introduced by Rep. Jamie Raskin, would declare Trump "unable to discharge the powers and duties of his office" and transfer power to Pence.

"We have made clear to the Vice President that we believe that the President has committed an impeachable offense and that we believe he should be removed from office," Pelosi said.

Meanwhile, the House Judiciary Committee has drafted impeachment charges against Trump, aiming for a vote as early as Wednesday. The charges allege that Trump "incited an insurrection against the United States" by encouraging his supporters to march on the Capitol and overturn the results of the election.

"The President of the United States summoned a mob to Washington, D.C., and ultimately spurred that mob to wage a violent assault on our democracy," said Rep. James Clyburn, the House Majority Whip.

The impeachment articles are expected to be sent to the Senate for a trial, but Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell has indicated that it likely wouldn't start before President-elect Joe Biden's inauguration on January 20th. This could potentially affect Biden's early agenda and the confirmation of his cabinet nominees.

Biden has not publicly taken a stand on impeachment, instead focusing on his upcoming agenda and the transition to his administration.

Some Republicans, including Sen. Ben Sasse, have expressed openness to impeachment. "If the President has committed an impeachable offense, we should follow the process laid out in the Constitution," Sasse said.

However, other Republicans, including McConnell, have remained silent on the issue since the attack. Sen. Lisa Murkowski said she is "considering all options," while Sen. Pat Toomey said he is "reviewing the evidence."

"I'm not going to make a judgment until I've had a chance to look at all the facts," Toomey said.

Sen. Roy Blunt said he believes the 25th Amendment is "not the right path" and that impeachment "would be a mistake."

In addition to impeachment, lawmakers are also considering censuring Trump and taking action against GOP objectors of Electoral College votes, including possible expulsion.

"We must hold those who incited this insurrection accountable," said Rep. Eleanor Holmes Norton.

Sen. Josh Hawley, who objected to the Electoral College results, said he is "not afraid" of being expelled. Sen. Ted Cruz, another objector, said he is "not going to be intimidated by the left."

Sen. Sheldon Whitehouse said he believes the Senate should "expel every single member who voted to overturn the election." Sen. Chris Coons said he supports censuring Trump but is "not sure" about expulsion.

"We need to make sure that we are not dividing the country further," Coons said.

Rep. Cori Bush said she believes Trump should be "removed from office immediately."

"He is a danger to our democracy," Bush said.

The impeachment process and the potential Senate trial are expected to be highly contentious and could further divide the country. However, Democrats are determined to hold Trump accountable for his actions and prevent him from causing further harm to the nation.

Archbishop Confirms Meghan and Harry's Private Vow Exchange Was Not Legally Binding

CNN – Archbishop of Canterbury Justin Welby has confirmed that Prince Harry and Meghan Markle were not legally married before their public ceremony in 2018.

In an interview with the BBC, Welby said that he signed the legal marriage document on the day of their public wedding at St. George's Chapel in Windsor on May 19, 2018.

"The legal wedding was on the Saturday," Welby said. "I signed the marriage certificate, which is a legal document, and I would have committed a serious criminal offense if I signed it knowing it was false."

Markle had previously revealed in an interview with Oprah Winfrey that she and Harry had a private exchange of vows three days before their public ceremony. However, the private ceremony did not have witnesses, leading to speculation that it was not legally binding.

Welby's clarification confirms that the couple's legal marriage took place on the day of their public wedding.

The revelation comes after Harry and Meghan stepped back from royal duties in January 2020. In their bombshell interview with Oprah, they discussed racism within the royal family and Meghan's mental health struggles.

One of the major revelations from the interview was that there were concerns within the royal family about the skin color of their unborn child, Archie.

The interview allowed Harry and Meghan to speak more freely about their experiences in the royal family.

"I think they're a very brave couple," Welby said. "They've been through a lot, and they've come out the other side."

Harry and Meghan have since settled in California with their two children, Archie and Lilibet.

Kamala Harris Makes History as First Female, Black, and South Asian Vice President

WASHINGTON (AP) – Kamala Harris shattered multiple glass ceilings Wednesday, becoming the first female, first Black, and first South Asian vice president of the United States.

In her inaugural address at the Lincoln Memorial, Harris hailed the moment as a testament to "American aspiration."

"Today, we mark the swearing-in of the first woman, the first Black woman, the first woman of South Asian descent, and the first daughter of immigrants to hold the second highest office in our land," she said. "And while I may be the first woman in this office, I will not be the last."

Harris was sworn in by Supreme Court Justice Sonia Sotomayor, using a Bible that belonged to Thurgood Marshall, the first Black Supreme Court justice. Capitol Police Officer Eugene Goodman, who defended the Capitol during the January 6 insurrection, escorted her to the podium.

Her inauguration is seen as a watershed moment in American history, representing significant progress in both gender and racial equality.

"This is a day of celebration and a day of reflection," said Lateefah Simon, a civil rights advocate and friend of Harris. "It's a reminder of how far we've come, but also how much work we still have to do."

Harris' diverse background is reflective of many Americans' stories, bringing important perspectives to the administration.

"She represents the future of our country," said Elizabeth Shelby, a member of the Alpha Kappa Alpha sorority, of which Harris is also a member. "She's a role model for young girls everywhere, showing them that anything is possible."

Harris presided over the Senate as Vice President for the first time Wednesday, swearing in three new Democratic senators.

Before becoming vice president, Harris served as a Senator from California and ran for the presidency herself.

Her historic inauguration was celebrated by members of the Alpha Kappa Alpha sorority and others across the country.

President Joe Biden mentioned Harris' historic election in his inaugural address, marking it as a sign of progress.

"We have a new vice president who represents the best of our nation," Biden said. "She's a trailblazer, a role model, and an inspiration."

Experts believe Harris' vice presidency will redefine political power in America and stress the significance of Black women's leadership.

"This is a historic moment that will have a lasting impact on our country," said Martha S. Jones, a professor of history at Johns Hopkins University. "Kamala Harris' election is a testament to the power of representation and the importance of diversity in our government."

Harris' inauguration is a reminder that the American dream is still alive and well. It is a day of celebration and a day of hope for a more just and equitable future.

Uncollected Garbage Plagues New Orleans Weeks After Hurricane Ida

New Orleans residents have endured weeks of uncollected garbage following Hurricane Ida, sparking frustration and a satirical protest.

Residents testified before a City Council committee about the issue, which they say has persisted since before the hurricane made landfall on Aug. 29. "The garbage has been piling up for weeks," said resident Mary Johnson. "It's a health hazard."

In response, resident Aaron "Louisiana" Grant proposed a Trash Parade on Facebook as a satirical protest. The event quickly gained traction, with over 1,900 interested participants.

On Saturday, approximately 150 protesters marched through the streets, showcasing creativity in their costumes to draw attention to the garbage problem. Grant, dressed as a giant piece of trash, said, "We're using humor as a coping mechanism in the aftermath of this disaster."

Despite the parade, garbage collection issues persist, with trash still visible everywhere. "It's a disgrace," said resident John Smith. "The city needs to do something about this."

New Orleans Mayor LaToya Cantrell acknowledged the garbage collection problems, attributing them to a workforce shortage exacerbated by Ida. "We're working to address this issue as quickly as possible," Cantrell said. "We're seeking help from outside contractors to supplement our sanitation crews."

Grant criticized the local government's failure to plan and prepare for such crises. "It's unacceptable that the city was not better prepared for this," Grant said. "We saw how quickly the electrical and healthcare sectors were able to mobilize after the hurricane. Why can't we do the same for sanitation services?"

The garbage crisis has become a symbol of the challenges facing New Orleans in the aftermath of Hurricane Ida. Residents are frustrated and demanding action from city officials.

"We've been through a lot," said resident Sarah Jones. "We deserve better than this."

Trump Impeached for Second Time, Charged with Inciting Capitol Riot

WASHINGTON (AP) – President Donald Trump was impeached by the U.S. House for a second time Wednesday, charged with "incitement of insurrection" after the Capitol riot, in the most bipartisan presidential impeachment in modern times.

The House voted 232-197 to impeach, with ten Republicans joining Democrats. The impeachment came in response to Trump's role in inciting a mob that stormed the U.S. Capitol on January 6, interrupting the certification of election results.

House Speaker Nancy Pelosi (D-Calif.) cited a "clear and present danger" posed by Trump, urging lawmakers to uphold their constitutional duties.

"We know that the President of the United States incited this insurrection, this armed rebellion against our common country," Pelosi said. "He must go. He is a clear and present danger to the nation that we all love."

In a response, Trump released a video statement calling for unity and condemning the violence, without mentioning the impeachment.

"I want to be very clear: I unequivocally condemn the violence that we saw last week," Trump said. "Violence and vandalism have absolutely no place in our country."

Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell (R-Ky.) indicated Trump committed impeachable offenses but has not decided how he will vote.

"The President of the United States has been impeached by the House of Representatives for high crimes and misdemeanors," McConnell said. "The Senate will consider the impeachment charges against the President and determine whether he should be convicted and removed from office."

The earliest the Senate could start an impeachment trial is the day before Trump's term ends, aiming also to prevent him from running again.

The impeachment resolution relies on Trump's incendiary rhetoric and falsehoods about the election outcome. It cites his speech on January 6, in which he urged supporters to "fight like hell" to overturn the results.

Security was tightened at the Capitol, including metal-detector screenings for House members, reflecting heightened concerns.

The impeachment proceeding drew on historical precedents, including the impeachment of War Secretary William Belknap in 1876 after his resignation.

Reactions from Lawmakers

House Republican Leader Kevin McCarthy (R-Calif.) condemned the violence but opposed impeachment.

"I believe impeaching the President at this time would have the opposite effect of bringing our country together when we need to get America back on track," McCarthy said.

Third-ranking House GOP leader Liz Cheney (R-Wyo.) supported impeachment, calling Trump's actions "a clear and present danger to our Republic."

"The President of the United States summoned this mob, assembled the mob, and lit the flame of this attack," Cheney said.

Representative Jim McGovern (D-Mass.) said the impeachment was necessary to hold Trump accountable.

"We cannot allow a President to incite an insurrection against our country and get away with it," McGovern said.

Representative Jason Crow (D-Colo.) said Trump's actions were "an attack on our democracy."

"We must hold him accountable for his actions," Crow said.

Representative Maxine Waters (D-Calif.) said Trump "must be removed from office immediately."

"He is a danger to our democracy," Waters said.

Representative Tom McClintock (R-Calif.) opposed impeachment, calling it "a political stunt."

"This is a partisan impeachment, pure and simple," McClintock said.

Reactions from Senators

Republican Senator Pat Toomey (Pa.) said Trump's actions were "impeachable offenses."

"The President's actions that day were a clear and present danger to our democracy," Toomey said.

Republican Senator Lisa Murkowski (Alaska) said she was "struggling" with the decision on whether to convict Trump.

"I take my constitutional responsibilities very seriously," Murkowski said. "I will be listening to the arguments presented by both sides and making my decision based on the facts and the law."

Historical Precedents

The impeachment of Trump is only the third time a U.S. president has been impeached. Andrew Johnson was impeached in 1868 and Bill Clinton in 1998. Both were acquitted by the Senate.

The impeachment of War Secretary William Belknap in 1876 is a historical precedent for impeaching an official after their resignation. Belknap was impeached by the House after he resigned from office amid allegations of corruption. He was acquitted by the Senate.

Next Steps

The House impeachment resolution will now be sent to the Senate for a trial. The trial is expected to begin the day before Trump's term ends.

If convicted by the Senate, Trump would be removed from office and Vice President Mike Pence would become president. Trump would also be barred from holding federal office again.

Tom Brady: The Unparalleled Legacy of a Super Bowl Legend

Tom Brady, the most decorated quarterback in NFL history, stands on the cusp of another Super Bowl triumph as he leads the Tampa Bay Buccaneers into Super Bowl 55. With an unparalleled resume boasting numerous records, Brady's quest for a seventh Vince Lombardi Trophy adds another chapter to his remarkable legacy.

A Quarterback for the Ages

Brady's dominance on the gridiron has been nothing short of extraordinary. He holds the NFL records for most career passing yards (84,520), most career passing touchdowns (624), most career regular season wins (243), and most career playoff wins (34). His six Super Bowl victories, nine Super Bowl appearances, and four Super Bowl MVP awards further cement his status as the greatest quarterback of all time.

Buccaneers' Postseason Surge

Despite Brady's arrival in Tampa Bay, the Buccaneers have yet to fully establish themselves as a postseason powerhouse. In their first season with Brady at the helm, they managed a modest 11-5 record and a Wild Card berth. However, their playoff run was cut short by the eventual Super Bowl champions, the Los Angeles Rams.

Super Bowl Records Within Reach

Super Bowl 55 presents Brady with an opportunity to extend his already remarkable Super Bowl record. He currently holds the records for most Super Bowl wins (6), most Super Bowl games played (9), and most Super Bowl MVP awards (4). Additionally, he holds the Super Bowl records for most pass attempts (421), most pass completions (271), most pass completions in a single game (43), most passing yards (3,039), and most touchdown passes (21).

Breaking New Ground

With another Super Bowl victory, Brady would become the first player in NFL history to win seven championships. He also has the chance to break the record for most touchdown passes in a single Super Bowl, currently held by Steve Young with six. However, Brady's quest for perfection is not without its challenges. He has thrown six interceptions in Super Bowl appearances, placing him fourth all time. Despite playing in nearly double the number of Super Bowls as John Elway, Brady trails Elway in total interceptions thrown.

A Legacy of Excellence

Regardless of the outcome of Super Bowl 55, Tom Brady's legacy as the greatest quarterback of all time is secure. His unparalleled success, both in the regular season and the playoffs, has cemented his place among the pantheon of sports legends. As he takes the field for his tenth Super Bowl appearance, Brady stands on the cusp of further etching his name into the annals of NFL history.

Additional Highlights of Brady's Super Bowl Records:

  • Most passing yards in a single Super Bowl: 505 yards (Super Bowl LI)
  • Most pass attempts in a single Super Bowl: 62 attempts (Super Bowl LI)
  • Most pass completions in a single Super Bowl: 43 completions (Super Bowl LI)
  • Most touchdown passes in a single Super Bowl: 5 touchdowns (Super Bowl LI, Super Bowl XXXIX)
  • Most interceptions thrown in a single Super Bowl: 3 interceptions (Super Bowl XLII)
  • Most consecutive Super Bowl wins: 3 wins (Super Bowl XXXVI, Super Bowl XXXVIII, Super Bowl XXXIX)
  • Most Super Bowl appearances by a quarterback: 9 appearances (Super Bowl XXXVI, Super Bowl XXXVIII, Super Bowl XXXIX, Super Bowl XLII, Super Bowl XLVI, Super Bowl LI, Super Bowl LII, Super Bowl LIII, Super Bowl LV)

CNN Producer Indicted for Luring Minors for Sexual Exploitation

New York, NY - John Griffin, a former CNN producer, has been indicted on federal charges for allegedly luring minors for unlawful sexual activities, including in the presence of young children. The disturbing allegations against Griffin have sent shockwaves through the community, raising concerns about the safety of children and the lengths to which some individuals will go to exploit them.

According to the indictment, Griffin allegedly offered large sums of money to women and their daughters for sexual acts, including in the presence of minors. He is facing three counts of attempted sexual exploitation of a minor, each carrying a potential sentence of up to 10 years in prison.

"The allegations against Mr. Griffin are deeply disturbing and represent a serious threat to the safety of our children," said US Attorney Nikolas P. Kerest. "We will not tolerate the exploitation of minors, and we will aggressively pursue those who engage in such heinous acts."

The indictment alleges that Griffin engaged in disturbing communications, including reassuring someone who sexually assaulted a baby. Prosecutors also allege that Griffin offered money for "sexual subservience" training sessions at his Vermont ski house for girls as young as 9.

One of the victims, a 9-year-old girl, was allegedly abused by Griffin and Heather Carriker, who was arrested for participating in the abuse of her own daughters at Griffin's house. The allegations surfaced through explicit texts discovered by one victim's biological mother.

Griffin is accused of attempting to use his wealth to influence the legal process, offering a family member of a victim $4,000 as a payoff. Despite previously enjoying privileges due to his wealth, Griffin now faces substantial legal and reputational risks.

"We must keep Mr. Griffin detained for the safety of the community," Kerest said. "His wealth and desperation to avoid justice make him a flight risk and a danger to the public."

The case against Griffin is a reminder of the importance of protecting children from sexual exploitation. It also highlights the need for vigilance in identifying and reporting suspected cases of abuse.

"We urge anyone with information about this case or any other case of child sexual exploitation to come forward," Kerest said. "We will not rest until justice is served for these victims."

Griffin is scheduled to appear in court for a detention hearing on Friday. If convicted, he faces a maximum sentence of 30 years in prison.

Tiger Woods Crash: Experts Question Sheriff's 'Accident' Ruling Amid Lack of Impairment Investigation

Los Angeles County Sheriff Alex Villanueva's hasty determination that Tiger Woods' February car crash was an "accident" has drawn criticism from forensic experts who argue that the investigation failed to thoroughly explore potential impairment.

"The sheriff's department jumped to conclusions without conducting a proper investigation," said Charles Schack, president of Crash Experts. "There are clear indications that Woods may have been impaired at the time of the crash."

Villanueva announced the day after the crash that there was "no evidence of impairment," but experts point to the lack of skid marks and Woods' inability to remember driving as signs of potential inattentiveness or impairment.

"The absence of skid marks suggests that Woods was not attempting to brake or steer away from the crash site," said Jonathan Cherney, a former detective. "This could indicate a lack of attention or impairment."

Accident reconstruction experts also criticized the sheriff's department for not having a drug recognition expert (DRE) evaluate Woods for signs of impairment.

"DREs are trained to identify signs of impairment that may not be immediately apparent," said Chris Taylor, managing attorney at Taylor & Taylor. "They could have determined the need for a blood test by examining Woods' medications, eyes, and vital signs."

A blood test could have identified any medications or drugs in Woods' system, potentially leading to charges of misdemeanor driving under the influence.

"It appears that the sheriff's department was more interested in protecting Woods' reputation than in conducting a thorough investigation," said Schack.

Cherney agreed, stating that the crash appeared to be a case of falling asleep at the wheel. "The absence of any attempts to brake or steer away from the crash site suggests a lack of attention or impairment."

It is now too late to access Woods' blood and medical reports without his cooperation or a search warrant. The sheriff's department obtained the SUV's "black box" data but has not released its findings.

"The public deserves to know the truth about what happened that day," said Taylor. "A thorough investigation should have been conducted, and the sheriff's department should be held accountable for its failure to do so."

Sheriff Villanueva's Response:

Sheriff Villanueva has defended his department's investigation, stating that there was no evidence to suggest that Woods was impaired.

"We conducted a thorough investigation and found no evidence of impairment," said Villanueva. "We stand by our conclusion that this was an accident."

Conclusion:

Chauvin's Knee on Floyd's Neck Now Estimated to Be at Least Nine Minutes

MINNEAPOLIS (AP) – Prosecutors in the trial of Derek Chauvin have adjusted the duration of time his knee was on George Floyd's neck to about nine minutes, according to recent filings.

The initial estimate was 8 minutes, 46 seconds, but was later corrected to 7:46 due to a mathematical error. However, recent filings citing police body-camera video have now adjusted the duration to at least nine minutes.

"The exact duration of the restraint is anticipated to be a significant part of the trial, relating to Floyd's cause of death and Chauvin's state of mind," said a former prosecutor who requested anonymity.

Chauvin is charged with second-degree murder and manslaughter for the death of Floyd, a 46-year-old Black man who died after Chauvin, a white police officer, knelt on his neck for an extended period during an arrest on May 25, 2020. Three other officers are charged with aiding and abetting second-degree murder and manslaughter and are scheduled for trial in August.

The 8:46 timing became symbolic, prompting demonstrations and acts of remembrance lasting 8 minutes, 46 seconds. However, prosecutors acknowledged a one-minute error in the initial timing but stated it would not affect the case.

"The revised timing from prosecutors indicates Chauvin's restraint lasted at least nine minutes but possibly up to 9 minutes, 31 seconds," said Toshira Garraway, founder of Families Supporting Families Against Police Violence. "This adjustment is significant because it provides a more accurate account of the length of time that Chauvin's knee was on Floyd's neck, which is a key factor in determining his culpability."

The discrepancies in the timing are not expected to impact Chauvin's trial, according to Garraway and the former prosecutor. They both emphasized that the focus of the trial should be on the totality of the evidence, including video footage, witness testimony, and expert analysis.

"While the exact duration of the restraint is important, it is not the only factor that will be considered by the jury," said the former prosecutor. "The jury will also need to consider the circumstances leading up to the restraint, Chauvin's intent, and the reasonableness of his actions."

The trial is expected to last several weeks and is being closely watched by the nation and the world. The outcome of the trial will have significant implications for police accountability and racial justice in the United States.

Alexander Kueng, Thomas Lane, and Tou Thao, on charges of violating George Floyd's civil rights, marking a significant escalation in the legal proceedings surrounding the high-profile case.

The federal charges, announced by the U.S. Attorney's Office for the District of Minnesota, allege that the officers deprived Floyd of his constitutional rights under the color of law, including the use of unreasonable force and deliberate indifference to his serious medical needs.

Chauvin, who was convicted on state charges of murder and manslaughter in April, faces an additional federal charge related to a separate 2017 incident involving excessive force against a 14-year-old.

"These charges are a reminder that no one is above the law," said U.S. Attorney Andrew Luger. "We will continue to investigate and prosecute those who violate the civil rights of our citizens."

Federal civil rights charges against law enforcement officers are relatively rare, with an average of 41 cases brought annually between 1990 and 2019. To convict the officers, prosecutors must prove that their actions were willful violations of Floyd's rights under the color of law.

"The federal charges are distinct from the state charges and carry their own potential consequences," said Mark Osler, a former federal prosecutor and professor at the University of St. Thomas School of Law. "The federal government has a different set of laws and sentencing guidelines that could result in more severe penalties."

Federal convictions could carry sentences ranging from 20 years to life in prison. Plea negotiations could potentially affect the charges or sentencing, but the outcome remains uncertain.

"The federal charges send a strong message that the Justice Department is committed to holding accountable those who violate the civil rights of our citizens," said Kenneth Udoibok, a civil rights lawyer. "It is a significant step towards ensuring that justice is served in this case."

The federal court proceedings' dates have not been set, and they are unlikely to be broadcast, unlike the state trials.

"The federal court proceedings will be more formal and less public than the state trials," said Rebeccah Parks, a spokesperson for the U.S. District Court in Minnesota. "The focus will be on the legal arguments and evidence presented by both sides."

Experts and legal professionals provide insights into the federal charges and potential outcomes for the officers.

"The federal charges are a serious matter and could result in significant consequences for the officers," said Rachel Moran, an associate professor of law at the University of St. Thomas. "The prosecution will need to prove that the officers' actions were intentional and willful violations of Floyd's rights."

The federal indictment marks a new chapter in the legal saga surrounding Floyd's death, which sparked widespread protests and calls for police reform across the country. The outcome of the federal trial will be closely watched as it could set a precedent for future cases involving police misconduct and civil rights violations.

German Court Rules Facebook's Post Deletions Illegal

BERLIN, July 29 – A top German court has ruled that Facebook acted illegally by taking down racist posts and blocking the author's account without notification or explanation.

The Federal Court of Justice's verdict adds complexity to the debate on toxic discourse on social networks ahead of Germany's general election. The judgment is significant as the comments in question violated Facebook's community standards on hate speech, which is also banned under German law.

The court declared Facebook's terms of service regarding post deletion and account blocking for community standards violations as "null and void." The ruling critiqued Facebook for not committing to inform users about post removal, account blocking reasons, or offering a right of appeal.

"The court's decision is a clear signal that Facebook cannot simply delete posts or block accounts without providing users with a proper explanation and the opportunity to appeal," said a company spokesperson for Facebook.

The specific post cited in the court ruling criticized German handling of "Islamist immigrants," alleging impunity for murder and rape. The post called for action from the Office for the Protection of the Constitution, Germany's main domestic security agency.

The court's decision highlights the challenges faced by social media companies in balancing freedom of expression with the need to combat hate speech and other harmful content.

"We have a zero-tolerance policy for hate speech on our platform," said the Facebook spokesperson. "We will continue to work with experts and law enforcement to effectively remove hate speech from our platform in Germany."

The ruling comes as Google also sought judicial review of a new German law (NetzDG) this week. Google cited privacy concerns due to the law's provisions for data sharing with law enforcement.

The German government has been criticized for its handling of hate speech on social media. In 2018, it passed the NetzDG law, which requires social media companies to remove illegal content within 24 hours or face fines.

However, critics argue that the law is too broad and could lead to the removal of legitimate content. The court's ruling against Facebook could further complicate the government's efforts to regulate hate speech on social media.

The verdict is expected to have significant implications for the upcoming German election, as social media platforms are expected to play a major role in the campaign. The ruling could make it more difficult for Facebook to remove hate speech and other harmful content from its platform, potentially leading to an increase in toxic discourse during the election.

Facebook Outage Costs Company $60 Million in Lost Revenue

The outage also had a negative impact on Facebook's stock price. Shares of Facebook dropped nearly 5% in after-hours trading, reducing CEO Mark Zuckerberg's net worth and ranking. The outage also led to a broader selloff in social media stocks, affecting shares of Twitter and Snap.

The outage is a reminder of the importance of social media platforms in our daily lives. Facebook, Instagram, WhatsApp, and Messenger are used by billions of people around the world to stay connected with friends and family, share news and information, and conduct business. The outage disrupted these activities and highlighted the potential financial impact of such disruptions.

Evergreen's Strict Management Under Scrutiny After Suez Canal Blockage

Washington, D.C. - Evergreen Marine Corp., the operator of the cargo ship that blocked the Suez Canal for nearly a week, is known for its strict, top-down management style. The accidental blockage of the canal by the Ever Given ship has raised questions about the company's management practices and the suitability of large vessels for certain shipping routes.

Strict Management Style

Evergreen Marine was founded in 1968 by Chang Yung-fa, a Taiwanese businessman known for his disciplined management style. The company has grown to operate a fleet of 200 container ships, making it one of the largest shipping companies in the world.

"Evergreen has a very strict management style," said Stone Huang, Taiwan Managing Director of JAS Worldwide. "They have a very top-down approach, and they are very focused on efficiency."

Suez Canal Blockage

On March 23, 2021, the Ever Given, a 400-meter-long container ship operated by Evergreen, became wedged across the Suez Canal, blocking all traffic through the vital waterway. The ship was freed after about a week, but the incident caused significant disruptions to global trade.

Evergreen cited gusty winds as a reason for the ship's deviation from its course. However, investigations are ongoing to determine the exact cause of the accident, focusing on the operator, shipowner, weather, or the canal itself.

Management Style Shift

After Chang Yung-fa's death in 2016, a dispute over inheritance among his sons was reported. Observers suggest that the management style at Evergreen may have shifted from its original strictness.

"There has been some speculation that the management style at Evergreen has changed in recent years," said Liang Kuo-yuan, President of the Polaris Research Institute. "It is possible that the company has become less disciplined and more focused on short-term profits."

Reputation Impact

Despite the Suez Canal incident, Evergreen Marine's reputation is unlikely to be significantly damaged. The company has a strong track record of safety and reliability, with minimal accidents prior to this incident.

"Evergreen has a good reputation in the industry," said Cathy Chin, Chairperson of the Taiwan International Logistics & Supply Chain Association. "They are known for their reliability and their commitment to customer service."

High Demand for Sea Freight

The high demand for sea freight due to the COVID-19 pandemic is also likely to mitigate any negative impact on Evergreen's reputation.

"The demand for sea freight is very high right now," said Huang. "Even if Evergreen's reputation is damaged, they will still be able to find customers for their services."

Large Vessel Suitability

The Suez Canal incident has also raised questions about the appropriateness of large vessels for certain shipping routes. The Ever Given is one of the largest container ships in the world, and its size may have contributed to the difficulty in freeing it from the canal.

"The Suez Canal incident shows that we need to be careful about the size of ships that we are using," said Chin. "We need to make sure that these ships are able to navigate safely through narrow waterways."

Ongoing Investigations

Investigations into the cause of the Suez Canal blockage are ongoing. The results of these investigations will likely have implications for Evergreen Marine, the shipping industry, and the design of future cargo ships.

Tragic House Fire in Sugar Land Claims Lives of Three Children and Grandmother

Nguyen, who is now facing the unimaginable loss of her children and mother, described them with love and admiration.

"Evan was my little comedian," Nguyen continued. "He always made me laugh. He loved to play soccer and was always running around."

"My mom was the most loving and supportive person I knew," she said. "She was always there for me and my children. She will be deeply missed."

  • Keep flammable materials away from heat sources.

  • Install smoke detectors and carbon monoxide detectors in your home.
  • Develop and practice a fire escape plan with your family.

The Sugar Land community is deeply saddened by this tragic loss and extends its heartfelt condolences to the Nguyen family.

Stimulus Payments End, Child Tax Credit Changes in 2022

BALTIMORE (WBFF/WKRC) – Stimulus check payments under the American Rescue Plan will end with 2021. Most Americans received $1,400 payments, along with expanded Child Tax Credit benefits. However, no more monthly child tax credit payments are planned for 2022.

The IRS is sending out "plus-up" payments to some families based on changes noted in their 2020 tax filings. These changes include lower income or having a child. "Plus-up" payments are available for individuals making $75,000 or less, or married couples making $150,000 or less. The IRS will continue to send out "plus-up" payments until December 31, based on the legislative deadline.

Democrats plan to continue efforts to extend the Child Tax Credit payments into 2022. A one-year extension of the Child Tax Credit would cost $185 billion. Extending the Child Tax Credit for 10 years would cost $1.6 trillion.

The Child Tax Credit was expanded under the American Rescue Plan, providing monthly payments of up to $300 per child under the age of 6 and $250 per child ages 6 to 17. The payments were intended to help families cover the costs of raising children, such as food, clothing, and childcare.

The expanded Child Tax Credit was a significant benefit for many families, but its future is uncertain. Democrats have proposed extending the credit, but Republicans have opposed the measure. It remains to be seen whether the Child Tax Credit will be extended in 2022.

In the meantime, families should be aware that the monthly Child Tax Credit payments will end with 2021. They should also be aware of the "plus-up" payments that are being sent out by the IRS. These payments are intended to make up for any underpayments that were made in 2021.

Rittenhouse Acquitted, Sparking National Debate on Self-Defense and Vigilantism

KENOSHA, Wis. – Kyle Rittenhouse, the 18-year-old who fatally shot two men and wounded another during protests in Kenosha, Wisconsin, was acquitted of all charges on Friday, November 19, 2021.

The verdict, which came after approximately 26 hours of jury deliberation, concluded a deeply divisive trial that ignited a national debate over vigilantism, gun rights, and self-defense.

Rittenhouse, who had become a national symbol during the trial, cried and hugged his lawyers after the jury's verdict was read, declaring him not guilty on multiple counts, including first-degree intentional homicide.

"I'm so relieved," Rittenhouse said outside the courthouse. "I've been waiting for this day for a long time."

The jury's decision accepted the defense's argument that Rittenhouse acted in self-defense when he shot three people amid unrest in Kenosha on August 25, 2020.

"We're very happy with the verdict," said Mark Richards, Rittenhouse's defense lawyer. "We believe that the jury got it right."

The prosecution, however, had attempted to portray Rittenhouse as an instigator who provoked the violence.

"This is a dangerous verdict," said Thomas Binger, the prosecutor. "It sends the message that you can bring a gun to a protest and shoot people if you feel threatened."

The verdict sparked strong reactions from political figures and the public, with opinions split along ideological lines.

Governor Gavin Newsom of California criticized the verdict, saying it "sends the wrong message" about vigilantism.

"This verdict is a miscarriage of justice," Newsom said. "It's a dangerous precedent that will allow vigilantes to roam our streets with impunity."

President Biden expressed concern about the verdict but urged for peaceful acceptance.

"While the verdict in Kenosha will leave many Americans feeling angry and concerned, myself included, we must acknowledge that the jury has spoken," Biden said. "I urge everyone to express their views peacefully."

Senator Ron Johnson, a Republican from Wisconsin, praised the verdict, saying it "affirms the right to self-defense."

"The jury saw through the prosecution's political agenda and made the right decision," Johnson said.

Rebecca Kleefisch, the Republican candidate for Wisconsin governor, also welcomed the verdict.

"This is a victory for the rule of law and for the Second Amendment," Kleefisch said.

Richards, Rittenhouse's defense lawyer, said his client looks forward to moving on with his life post-verdict.

"Kyle is a good kid who made a mistake," Richards said. "He's not a murderer. He's not a vigilante. He's just a kid who was trying to do the right thing."

The trial examined the events of August 25, 2020, when Rittenhouse, armed with an AR-15-style rifle and claiming to offer medical aid, shot three people amid unrest in Kenosha.

The prosecution argued that Rittenhouse provoked the violence by pointing his gun at protesters and that he was not justified in using deadly force.

The defense, however, argued that Rittenhouse acted in self-defense after being attacked by protesters.

The jury ultimately agreed with the defense's argument, finding that Rittenhouse reasonably believed that he was in imminent danger of being killed or seriously injured.

The verdict has reignited the national debate over gun rights, self-defense, and the role of vigilantes in society. It is a complex and controversial issue that will likely continue to be debated for years to come.

East Coast Transit Systems Face Urgent Need for Climate Resilience

NEW YORK (AP) – The devastation wrought by Hurricane Ida and other summer storms has laid bare the urgent need for improved climate resilience in East Coast transit systems. Despite billions of dollars spent on coastal flooding protection since Superstorm Sandy, recent events have shown that much more work is necessary.

"The recent storms have been a wake-up call," said Sanjay Seth, Boston's "climate resilience" program manager. "We need to be doing more to protect our transit systems from the impacts of climate change."

One of the most ambitious proposals is a plan to build a series of canals in New York City to divert floodwaters away from subway stations. The city is also considering installing curbs at subway entrances to prevent water ingress.

"We need to think big and be bold in our approach to climate resilience," said Janno Lieber, Acting CEO of the Metropolitan Transit Authority. "These canals would provide a vital layer of protection for our subway system."

In Boston, climate change efforts are focused on the Blue Line, which runs along the city's waterfront. Plans are underway to build a seawall and upgrade pumps to protect the line from flooding.

"The Blue Line is one of our most vulnerable assets," said Joe Pesaturo, a spokesperson for the Massachusetts Bay Transportation Authority. "We need to make sure it's protected from future storms."

Philadelphia has seen mixed success with its post-Sandy flood protection measures. While some areas have been protected, others have still experienced flooding.

"We're still learning and adapting," said Bob Lund, Deputy General Manager of the Southeastern Pennsylvania Transportation Authority. "We're going to continue to armor our shorelines with concrete blocks and explore other options to improve our resilience."

In Washington, D.C., the WMATA is developing a climate resiliency plan. The agency has already upgraded its drainage systems and installed pumping stations to reduce flooding.

"We're taking a comprehensive approach to climate resilience," said Sherrie Ly, a spokesperson for the Washington Metropolitan Area Transit Authority. "We're looking at everything from infrastructure improvements to operational changes."

Despite these efforts, there are concerns that transit systems are not planning ambitiously enough for the challenges posed by climate change.

"We need to be thinking about more than just protecting existing infrastructure," said Jesse Keenan, an associate professor at Tulane University. "We need to be rethinking how we design and build our transit systems to make them more resilient to future storms."

Michael Martello, a researcher at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, agrees. "We need to be investing in research and development to come up with new and innovative solutions to the challenges of climate change," he said.

Funding remains a major challenge for implementing ambitious climate change projects in transit systems. Many agencies are already facing budget constraints, and the cost of climate resilience measures can be significant.

"We need to find creative ways to finance these projects," said Lieber. "We can't afford to wait any longer to protect our transit systems from the impacts of climate change."

The challenges facing East Coast transit systems are not unique. Global cities like London and Zhengzhou have also struggled with flood management in their transit systems.

"This is a global problem," said Keenan. "We need to share best practices and work together to find solutions."

As the climate continues to change, the need for climate resilience in transit systems will only become more urgent. By investing in innovative solutions and working together, we can create transit systems that are resilient to the challenges of the future.

Landmark Study Confirms Safety, Effectiveness of COVID-19 Vaccines in Real-World Setting

Boston, MA - Recent clinical trials have demonstrated the remarkable effectiveness and safety of COVID-19 vaccines, and now, a groundbreaking study published in The New England Journal of Medicine provides compelling real-world evidence to support these findings.

The study, conducted by researchers from Clalit Research Institute, Harvard Medical School (HMS), and the Harvard T.H. Chan School of Public Health, analyzed data from nearly 2 million individuals in Israel, offering a comprehensive assessment of the safety and effectiveness of the Pfizer/BioNTech BNT162b2 mRNA vaccine in a large-scale, real-world setting.

"This study provides robust evidence of the safety and effectiveness of the Pfizer/BioNTech vaccine in a real-world setting, which is critical for addressing vaccine hesitancy and building public trust," said Ben Reis, HMS assistant professor of pediatrics, director of the predictive medicine group, and Computational Health Informatics Program at Boston Children's.

Safety Profile: Rare Adverse Events, Myocarditis Risk Outweighed by COVID-19 Infection

The study found that the Pfizer/BioNTech vaccine was associated with few adverse events, with myocarditis (inflammation of the heart muscle) being the most common. The rate of myocarditis was 2.7 excess cases per 100,000 vaccinated people, primarily occurring within the first week after the second dose and more frequently in young males.

However, the researchers emphasized that the risk of myocarditis and other serious conditions was significantly higher among unvaccinated individuals infected with SARS-CoV-2, the virus that causes COVID-19.

"The risk of myocarditis is much lower with vaccination than with natural infection," said Ran Balicer, director of the Clalit Research Institute, Chief Innovation Officer for Clalit, and chairman of Israel's National Expert Advisory Team on COVID-19 response. "The benefits of vaccination far outweigh the risks."

Effectiveness: Substantial Protection Against Infection, Hospitalization, and Death

The study also confirmed the high effectiveness of the Pfizer/BioNTech vaccine in preventing COVID-19 infection, hospitalization, and death. The vaccine was found to be 95% effective in preventing symptomatic COVID-19, 98% effective in preventing hospitalization, and 99% effective in preventing death.

These findings are consistent with the results of the Pfizer/BioNTech phase 3 randomized clinical trial, which demonstrated 95% efficacy in preventing symptomatic COVID-19.

Parallel Analysis: Assessing a Range of Potential Adverse Events

In a parallel analysis, the researchers assessed 25 potential adverse events in vaccinated versus unvaccinated individuals. While most events were not associated with vaccination, a few were moderately associated, including lymph node swelling, appendicitis, and reactivation of herpes zoster. However, these events were rare.

Implications for Vaccine Hesitancy and Public Health

The findings of this study are expected to have a significant impact on vaccine hesitancy issues by providing comprehensive safety information.

"This study offers reassurance about the safety of mRNA vaccines and highlights the higher risks of 'natural' coronavirus morbidity," said Balicer. "It should help people make informed decisions about vaccination."

Reis added, "This study complements the findings from the Pfizer/BioNTech phase 3 clinical trial and provides further evidence of the safety and effectiveness of COVID-19 vaccines. It is a valuable contribution to the scientific literature and should help build public trust in vaccines."

Conclusion

The study published in The New England Journal of Medicine provides compelling real-world evidence of the safety and effectiveness of the Pfizer/BioNTech BNT162b2 mRNA vaccine. The findings reinforce the importance of vaccination in protecting individuals and communities from COVID-19 and should help address vaccine hesitancy issues.

Ever Given Grounding Triggers Legal Storm Over General Average

The grounding of the Ever Given in the Suez Canal has ignited a legal and insurance dispute involving the principle of general average, a centuries-old maritime tradition that requires shippers to share losses.

General average is the equitable sharing of loss between vessel owners and cargo interests under the York Antwerp Rules. It can be invoked for various reasons beyond vessel fires or overboard containers, including salvage operations and seeking refuge.

In the case of the Ever Given, the vessel's owners, not Evergreen specifically, invoked general average for the incident. The move has sparked a legal battle over who should bear the costs of the salvage operation, which freed the vessel after six days.

"General average is a complex area of maritime law that can be difficult to understand," said Joe Klobus, Claims and Insurance Manager at OEC Group. "It's important for shippers to be aware of the potential implications of general average before entering into contracts."

The increasing frequency of incidents like containers falling overboard has made general average declarations more common. In 2021, there were 3,114 reported incidents of containers lost at sea, according to the World Shipping Council.

Evergreen, while not technically liable, faces a public and legal challenge regarding the financial implications of the blockade. The company has been criticized for its handling of the situation and could face lawsuits from shippers who suffered losses due to the delay.

The $900 million figure cited by Egyptian authorities includes various claims, with $300 million each for a salvage bonus and loss of reputation. The remaining $300 million is for other costs, including damage to the canal and lost revenue.

Vessels delayed due to the Ever Given's grounding likely cannot declare general average as delay doesn't fit within the York Antwerp Rules. However, they may be able to claim compensation from the vessel's owners or their insurers.

Shippers entering contracts should be aware of general average, though many may not understand its full implications. Klobus recommends that shippers seek legal advice before signing contracts that include general average clauses.

"General average can be a significant financial burden for shippers," Klobus said. "It's important to understand the risks involved and to take steps to mitigate those risks."

The Ever Given incident has highlighted the importance of general average in maritime law. As the shipping industry becomes more complex and globalized, general average disputes are likely to become more common.

Understanding General Average

General average is a maritime principle that dates back to the Middle Ages. It is based on the idea that all parties involved in a maritime venture should share the costs of any extraordinary sacrifices made for the common good.

The York Antwerp Rules, which were first adopted in 1890, codify the principles of general average. The rules have been updated several times over the years, most recently in 2016.

General average can be invoked for a variety of reasons, including:

  • Vessel fires
  • Overboard containers
  • Salvage operations
  • Seeking refuge

When general average is invoked, the vessel's owners appoint a general average adjuster to calculate the total cost of the loss. The adjuster then apportions the cost among the vessel owners and cargo interests based on the value of their respective interests.

Shippers can take steps to mitigate the risk of general average, such as:

  • Purchasing insurance
  • Negotiating contracts that limit their liability
  • Diversifying their cargo across multiple vessels

Impact on Consumer Prices

The Ever Given incident could have a ripple effect on consumer prices. The charges levied against the Ever Given and other ships could be rolled into landed costs, affecting the market.

"Consumers should be aware that the Ever Given incident could lead to higher prices for goods," Klobus said. "It's important to factor this into their budgeting decisions."

The Ever Given incident is a reminder of the importance of general average in maritime law. Shippers should be aware of the potential implications of general average before entering into contracts.

Individuals with an adjusted gross income (AGI) of $80,000 or less, heads of households with an AGI of $120,000 or less, and married couples filing jointly with an AGI of $160,000 or less are eligible for the full $1,400 payment.

WHO Designates New COVID-19 Variant as Variant of Concern, Omicron

Geneva, 26 November 2021 - The World Health Organization (WHO) today announced that the Technical Advisory Group on SARS-CoV-2 Virus Evolution (TAG-VE) has designated the B.1.1.529 variant of SARS-CoV-2, first reported to WHO from South Africa on 24 November 2021, as a Variant of Concern (VOC) and assigned it the Greek letter Omicron.

Background

The B.1.1.529 variant was first identified in South Africa and has since been detected in several other countries. The variant has a large number of mutations, including some that are concerning because they may affect the behavior of the virus.

Assessment by TAG-VE

TAG-VE convened on 26 November 2021 to assess the B.1.1.529 variant. The group reviewed the available evidence, including data on the variant's transmissibility, severity, and immune escape potential.

Designation as a Variant of Concern

Based on the evidence, TAG-VE advised that the B.1.1.529 variant should be designated as a VOC. This designation is based on the variant's increased transmissibility, potential for immune escape, and the risk of severe disease.

WHO's Response

WHO has communicated the designation of Omicron as a VOC to all member states and will continue to update them on new findings. WHO is also working with partners to enhance surveillance, sequencing, and reporting of cases associated with VOC infection.

Public Health Measures

Individuals are reminded to continue adhering to public health measures, including:

  • Wearing a mask
  • Maintaining physical distance
  • Washing hands frequently
  • Getting vaccinated

Definitions

  • Variant of Interest (VOI): A variant with genetic changes that are predicted or known to affect virus characteristics such as transmissibility, disease severity, immune escape, or diagnostic or therapeutic escape.
  • Variant of Concern (VOC): A variant that has been associated with an increase in transmissibility, severity, or immune escape.

Additional Information

WHO will continue to monitor the situation closely and provide updates as new information becomes available. For more information, please visit the WHO website: www.who.int/emergencies/diseases/novel-coronavirus-2019

Cloud Misconfigurations: A Critical Threat to Business and Security

FREDERICK, Md. – Recent high-profile incidents involving Facebook and Twitch have brought the issue of cloud misconfigurations to the forefront of business and security concerns. These incidents, which resulted in substantial losses for both companies, underscore the critical need for organizations to address this growing threat.

"The Facebook outage and Twitch breach are stark reminders of the devastating consequences that cloud misconfigurations can have on businesses," said Josh Stella, CEO and Co-founder of Fugue. "These incidents highlight the urgent need for organizations to prioritize cloud security and implement proactive measures to mitigate misconfiguration risks."

The Rise of Cloud Misconfigurations

Cloud misconfigurations are a major source of vulnerability in cloud environments. According to a recent study, 36% of companies experienced a serious cloud security leak or breach due to misconfiguration in the past year. This is a significant increase from previous years, indicating that misconfigurations are becoming a more common and dangerous threat.

The shift to cloud computing has introduced a new set of security challenges. In traditional on-premises environments, the network was the primary attack surface. However, in cloud environments, configuration is now the main attack surface. This is because cloud environments are constantly changing, with new resources being provisioned and modified on a regular basis. Every modification introduces the risk of misconfiguration.

The Impact of Cloud Misconfigurations

Misconfigurations in the cloud can lead to a wide range of vulnerabilities and operational disruptions. For example, a misconfigured security group can allow unauthorized access to sensitive data, while a misconfigured load balancer can cause a website or application to become unavailable.

Hackers are increasingly using automation to find and exploit cloud misconfigurations. This allows them to quickly identify and target vulnerable systems, often without being detected. As a result, organizations are facing a growing risk of unauthorized access, data breaches, and other security incidents.

Mitigating Misconfiguration Risks

Business and security leaders need to take immediate steps to address the threat of cloud misconfigurations. The following measures are recommended:

  • Know the Current State of Your Cloud Environments: Conduct a thorough assessment of your cloud environments to identify any existing misconfigurations. This assessment should include a review of all cloud resources, including infrastructure, applications, and data.
  • Implement Preventive Cloud Security Measures: Implement preventive cloud security measures, such as Policy as Code, to mitigate misconfiguration risks. Policy as Code allows organizations to define and enforce security policies in their cloud environments, reducing the risk of misconfigurations.
  • Shift Toward Security-Focused Practices: Make a cultural and operational shift toward security-focused practices in cloud management. This includes training staff on cloud security best practices and implementing processes to ensure that security is considered in all aspects of cloud operations.

"Cloud misconfigurations are a serious threat to businesses of all sizes," said Stella. "By taking proactive steps to mitigate these risks, organizations can protect their data, applications, and reputation."

About Fugue

Fugue is the leader in cloud configuration security. Fugue's Policy as Code platform enables organizations to define and enforce security policies across their cloud environments, reducing the risk of misconfigurations and ensuring compliance. Fugue is trusted by leading organizations, including Fortune 500 companies and government agencies, to protect their cloud environments.

El Paso's Winter Storm Resilience: A Tale of Preparation and Interconnection

While much of Texas grappled with widespread power outages and disruptions during a historic winter storm, El Paso emerged as an oasis of stability. The city's residents enjoyed uninterrupted utilities and fully stocked stores, a stark contrast to the chaos that engulfed other parts of the state.

"It was like a different world," said El Paso resident Robert Gomez. "I went to the grocery store, and it was fully stocked. The power was on. It was like nothing was happening."

El Paso's resilience can be attributed to several factors, including its preparation for winter storms following a devastating 2011 event. The city invested heavily in winterizing its infrastructure, including power plants and distribution lines. Additionally, El Paso's connection to the Western Interconnection grid, which spans 13 western states, allowed it to draw power from neighboring states during the storm.

"We have a very robust winterization program," said Steve Buraczyk, Senior Vice President of Operations at El Paso Electric. "We've spent millions of dollars over the years to make sure that our facilities are prepared for extreme weather events."

In contrast, the Electric Reliability Council of Texas (ERCOT), which manages about 90% of Texas's electric load, was unable to draw power from other states during the storm. This was due to ERCOT's isolation from the national grid and its lack of interconnections with neighboring states.

"ERCOT is an island," said Ramanan Krishnamoorti, Chief Energy Officer at the University of Houston. "It's not connected to the rest of the country, so it can't import power when it needs it."

El Paso Electric, on the other hand, has invested heavily in winterizing its facilities, including the construction of the Montana Power Station, which has dual-fuel capability and can switch between natural gas and diesel fuel.

"We've taken a very proactive approach to winterization," said Buraczyk. "We've spent millions of dollars on our facilities, and we've also developed a comprehensive winterization plan."

Many Texas power companies ignored voluntary winterization guidelines issued by ERCOT following the 2011 outages. This lack of preparation left them vulnerable to the extreme weather conditions that hit the state during the recent storm.

"The voluntary guidelines were not enough," said Carey King, Assistant Director at the University of Texas's Energy Institute. "We need mandatory winterization standards in Texas."

El Paso Electric's participation in the Western Interconnection incentivizes winterization for selling excess energy out-of-state. This creates a financial incentive for the company to invest in winterizing its facilities.

"The Western Interconnection provides us with a market for our excess energy," said Buraczyk. "This gives us an incentive to winterize our facilities so that we can sell our energy when it's needed."

Calls for mandatory winterization in Texas have risen in the wake of the recent storm, with responsibility falling on state legislators and agencies. Some experts believe that policy change is necessary to avoid future outages.

"We need to change the market rules in Texas," said Krishnamoorti. "We need to create incentives for power companies to winterize their facilities."

Others argue that altering market rules could have unintended consequences.

"We need to be careful about changing market rules," said King. "We don't want to create unintended consequences that could make the problem worse."

Despite El Paso's resilience, the widespread suffering in Texas highlights systemic failures in policy and planning. The state's reliance on a single grid operator, ERCOT, and the lack of mandatory winterization standards left millions of Texans without power and heat during a historic storm.

"The recent storm was a wake-up call for Texas," said King. "We need to take a hard look at our energy policies and make sure that we're prepared for future extreme weather events."

The ultrawealthy's income rarely comes from wages but from flexible sources such as investments and business ventures. This allows them to minimize taxes via losses and deductions.
